w:r.w:t: This document will present several problems which you will need to solve.
For this mini team work, you will have to implement a simulation of Single-Page Application (SPA).
The teamwork will be divided into 2 parts. You will be given the first part in this document, and the second – in another document.
This is done so that you can divide your work and
do it efficiently, instead of wondering where to start from.
You will be given a skeleton, which will include:
All of the JS files / classes / objects, however, you will need to implement them, since some
You will also be given 5 test objects … Which you will only be able to use, if you implement your classes correctly.

Do not modify, by any way, the naming of the files, classes, objects, properties etc. unless you are told so. Follow all instructions which were given to you, strictly, otherwise the project might break
The project will require a lot of work with the DOM, but most of it will be described thoroughly, so follow every step that has been given to you.
The Project is called “PunchStarter”. It’s a unique system inspired by the KickStarter idea. There are 5 main PunchStarter types.
You must implement a class for each
, as well as a base class for all
The project supports functionalities like creating a PunchStarter, viewing a list of PunchStarters, viewing detailed information about a certain PunchStarter… and so on.
The project is a web application, and as such it has several states (pages), which are controlled by
Each model is a class which has two main methods – render() and attachEvents(). These methods are used to render all the html needed for the current page, and attach all
events to the elements that have been added.
Well let’s start with few screenshots on what you will be implementing today.
The screenshots up until now, were for ‘not logged in session’. This is what we will see when we log in.
What we’ve seen up until now, were screenshots, of basically, what we need to render today. There is much more functionality left, but we will reveal that later in the teamwork.
Take a look at the skeleton, try to understand how things work at least on a base level, before you start doing the tasks.
